p: Identifying drivers of animal population demographics (i.e., associations between environmental conditions and vital rates) and locating where they operate is necessary for steering efforts to optimize wildlife species management and conservation (e.g., Caughley, 1994; Mills, 2007). Doing so establishes a foundation to evaluate how climate change may impact an animal's population growth and vulnerability (Brook et al., 2009). This information is especially critical for recovering species endangered with extinction (Akçakaya, Butchart, Watson, & Pearson, 2014). Herein, we focus on the population growth of endangered whooping cranes ( Grus americana), which hinges on recruitment (Butler, Metzger, & Harris, 2014).
